I think there are three ways to fix it.
1.Do not show tooltips when FF is unfocused. I can hardly imagine why someone want to see the tooptips when they are currently on another application.
2.Show tooltips when FF is unfocused, but don't cover the activated application (don't on top of everthing).
3.When FF is unfocused, still detect mouse movement, so you can know mouse is already moved out of the area that could triger tooltips.

comments.raw_text: Ok, but I think the basic reason is that when FF is not focused (unactivated) you can still triger the tooltips of FF, so you can try this: open another application(e.g. NOTEPAD.EXE),switch to FF then switch back in order to keep Notepad the activated App and FF is in the background. by default the Notepad is not in maximized mode, so you can drag it very close to the nav-bar of FF, preferably cover half of the nav-bar, then move your mouse over a nav-bar item(say Home button), you will see the tooltip of Home button are covering Notepad. Now you might already know why this bug occurs. To exactly reproduce the scenario I reported, you need quickly move your mouse to Notepad when the tooltip just appears, the trick is "keep trying". And the slower your CPU is the higher chances of it occuring. so you might need opening some high CPU consuming applications on the background, otherwise you may never see it happen.

I can make this happen reliably:
1. Drag another window so that it partially overlaps the toolbar button.
2. Without focusing Firefox, hover the mouse over the button.
3. Without leaving the area of the button, move the mouse into the foreground window.

The tooltip will not disappear until either you mouse over it or move the mouse back into the Firefox window.

comments.text:
Still reproducible with Firefox 14.01 on Windows XP (x86) and quite annoying. Almost every minimizing of Firefox leaves a Firefox tooltip on the desktop or any other application getting the focus.

Please consider adding a preference like 'applicationBlurDelay = n[ms]'. It should define the time to wait before Firefox starts actions resulting in loosing the focus (like minimize or exit). So the application has enough time to remove the tooltip - before further painting operations would be impossible.

comments.text:
My previous replication method seems to be fixed but I've found another one:

1. Maximize Firefox.
2. Display the Add-on Bar if not already.
3. Set the Windows taskbar to show on the bottom if not already.
4. Switch to a different application.
5. Focus Firefox by clicking in the main view area.
6. Move the mouse over the Add-on Bar's close button.
7. Before the tooltip appears, move the mouse further down onto the taskbar.

The "Close Add-on Bar" tooltip should remain onscreen and never go away until you move the mouse back into the Firefox window.
comments.creator: edwardsgreg@gmail.com
